text: 750ml corked bottle. Pours a cloudy ruby-brown with a medium, frothy, long lasting, tan head that laces. Sweet aroma of caramel malt, wheat, bread, dark fruit, overripe banana and maple. Sweet flavour of caramel malt, wheat, dark fruit, overripe banana, maple and spice with a warming alcohol finish. Medium to full body with a sticky, oily texture and soft carbonation. Excellent. A complex, world class weizenbock.

Ruby/brown opaque pour with a thin tan head. Aroma has dark fruits and doughy malts...a touch of a leathery/earthy note. Flavor follows suit...nice balance of flavors with nothing dominating...touch of spice creeping in...reminiscent of a dubbel as much as a weizenbock. Mouthfeel is medium and silky with an earthy/fruity almost woody finish.

Had a slight pop when I open the bottle still its somewhat flat. Aromas basically caramel toffee malt. Flavors good with the above malt, fruit, sweet and a bit tart. Better carbonation would have helped a lot.

Poured into weizen glass, the appearance was a dark ruby red color with a two finger white foamy head that dissipated at a moderate pace. Some clingy foamy messy lace.
The aroma brings together some clove, apple cider, raisins, caramel and sweet wheat up front. Light dark chocolate and then a light fig-like to molasses sweetened wheat bread comes in nicely.
The flavor melds the spice to the sweet through all of the previously mentioned aromas. Seems like a bit of mulled cider comes through in the taste. Wheaty to semi-sticky sweet aftertaste biting into the finish.
On the palate, this one sat about medium on the body, maybe just a touch under. Carbonation seems a bit more than expected. And with the spices coming across the way they do, this one seems to be a bit harsher on my tongue than some other weizenbocks Ive had.
Overall, for the most part, aroma and flavor is what really makes this beer great. The mouthfeel, well, its a bit pricklier than expected. I could still have again.

750 ml corked and caged bottle purchased at brewery in Brossard, Quebec. Poured into small Sam Adams Utopias snifter. Slightly cloudy brownish-red color. Visible carbonation, yet no head or lacing. Has a distinct balsamic vinegar and apple cider aroma, which is a little off-putting even though its appropriate for the style; thankfully, I also detect raisins, caramel and, oddly, soy sauce. Flavor is of all the above  minus the vinegar, mercifully  along with dark-chocolate-covered cherries, figs, dates, plantains sautéed in brandy, whole wheat molasses bread. Medium bodied with prickly carbonation on the tongue; slightly oily mouthfeel along with a spicy, smoky, yeasty softness and the slightest hop bitterness. It tastes as if its been oak-barrel aged, yet it hasnt; its simply the magic of the wheat-based ingredients, which happen to be 100 percent sourced from Quebec  a respectable distinguishing factor about this brewery. This beer, with this sweet and savory taste profile and its 10.5 percent alcohol, is definitely an appetizer or dessert sipper  and what an enjoyable one it is!

Average creamy frothy offwhite head. Good lacing. Mostly diminishing. Cloudy thick dark reddish-brown body. Aroma: moderate toasted malty, caramel, citrus lemon, raisin, plum. Initial flavor: heavy sweet. Final flavor: heavy sweet,light acidic and moderate bitter; long duration. Palate: medium full body, oily texture, lively carbonation, metallic and moderate alcoholic finish. Mesmo com o relativo equilíbrio oferecido pelo amargor do lúpulo northern brewer e do ligeiro azedume lembrando ameixa fresca, a cerveja tem excessivo dulçor maltado/caramelado, tornando-a enjoativa. Com o ganho de temperatura, tal acidez aumenta, equilibrando um pouco mais a cerveja, mas fugindo das diretrizes do estilo (BJCP) uma vez que a acidez não está prevista para uma weizenbock. Em minha opinião, equilibra bem, no entanto. Apesar de aroma e sabor fugirem das BJCP, a meu ver é uma interessante interpretação do estilo, diferenciada, saborosa, uma vez que as Weizenbock geralmente são bem repetitivas. Médio aquecimento alcoólico e média drinkability. Apesar disso, a cerveja consegue esconder relativamente bem o alto teor alcoólico de 10,5%.

UPDATED: NOV 2, 2015 Embouteillée le 16/04/2015, bue après 6 mois. Robe brune-orangée légèrement voilée avec de beaux reflets ambrés. Léger col de mousse blanchâtre qui disparaît rapidement. Arômes de canne à sucre, marmelade à lorange et abricot, bananes, alcool, et pruneaux. Nez très sucré, moyennement complexe, intense et précurseur de diabète. En bouche, on est immédiatement assaillies par des saveurs sucrées. Encore de la canne à sucre, beurre dérable, écorce dorange et fruits confits. Plutôt maltée aussi, esters fruités de bananes, muscade et un peu de clou de girofle. Aucune chance au houblon de se démarquer. Lalcool perçu au nez est ici bien caché. Je décèle un côté noisette grilleé en finale mais cest vraiment perdu dans cette dose de sucre qui relègue les gâteaux de maman Dion au rang damateur. Une belle texture épaisse et un corps rond, très rond. Malgré cette avalanche de calories, cette bière est doté dun équilibre presque sans faille. Nétant pas moi-même fan de bières sucrées, je dois avouer que celle-ci ma charmée. À boire température cellier et lentement. Il ne me manquait quun bon gouda vieilli.

En fût au Brouhaha lors dune dégustation verticale trouée - 2010, 2011 et 2014. La plus jeune est dune couleur très peu attirante. Dun brun/orange très opaque, son côté très boueux ma peu séduit. Les deux plus vieilles quant à elles étaient plus jolies. Il faut croire que le liquide se clarifie quelque peu avec le temps et coiffe une robe dune couleur qui tend vers des teintes pourpres. Au nez, la plus jeune sen sort pas mal (quel début de phrase douteux...) avec des arômes principalement composés de sucre dorge et de bananes. Beaucoup de sucre. Ces arômes sont étonnamment très sensibles au temps car les 2011 et 2010 exposaient des arômes dacidité importants. Joserais même ajouter un nez vinaigré et quelque peu fongique. Pour les trois années, le palais et la langue est très cohérente avec le nez. Aucune surprise. Bref, lexpérience fut intéressante même si ce type de bière nest absolument pas le mien. Objectivement, la Weizenbock est une réussite dans son style respectif et je la recommande.

UPDATED: MAR 8, 2015 Bière brune pâle tirant vers lorangée-cuivrée, bien voilée, bonne effervescence, et surmontée dun col brunâtre pas tellement large, mais bien dense, mousseux et persistant. Arômes de malt et de levure à weizen. Effluves de pain légèrement grillé, pâtisserie, pâte à pain, grain moyennement rôti, noisette, léger sucré (caramel, érable et crème brûlée), et léger fruits foncés confits (raisins secs, pruneaux, dattes). La levure amène des arômes de banane très mûre et léger clou de girofle, eucalyptus et vanille. Cependant, jai bu cette bière à plusieurs reprises, et je dois dire quelle présente malheureusement parfois de subtiles odeurs esters excessifs (solvant, vernis). Nez moyennement agréable, complexité élevée, bonne intensité. En bouche, pétillement moyen-faible sur la langue, mais onctuosité élevée au palais, le breuvage est soyeux et velouté. Au goût, entrée en bouche bien malté et sucré, pain légèrement grillé, pâtisserie, noisette, plus sucré quau nez (abondant caramel et sirop dérable!), et fruits foncés confits. La levure à weizen est moins présente en bouche quau nez, mais il y a définitivement une saveur de banane bien mûre, de banane caramélisé. Lalcool est présent au goût, mais cest très bien intégré, on perçoit surtout son aspect chaleureux en gorge et dans lestomac. La finale amène un certain houblon qui semble surtout floral, peut-être légèrement mentholé, en route vers une amertume somme toute assez légère mais tout de même bien sentie. Cest pas mal sucré comme bière, mais personnellement, jaime bien ça. Bonne intensité en bouche, mais complexité un peu plus faible quau nez, et qui aurait certainement pu être un peu mieux considérant le style. Mais, il sagit définitivement dune très bonne bière! /// Sur la bouteille, il est indiqué quun vieillissement de 3 à 5 ans est possible. Jai donc laissé une bouteille en cellier pendant 3 ans. Au visuel, la bière était plus foncée avec présence de particules pouvant être assez grosses, et au nez, des notes doxydation (carton) sont apparues. Au goût, jai cependant noté peu de différences, peut-être un certain adoucissement, voire affadissement des saveurs. Donc, pas vraiment de bonification liée au vieillissement. Jai dautres bouteilles en cellier, jessaierai un vieillissement de 5 ans, voire 6 ans
(bottle) clear reddish amber colour with a small tan head; aromas of molasses, spice; sweet complex flavour; very tasty

What a great beer. Appearance is nice, with a spare head and good lacing. Colour is a cloudy orange-red. Aroma is loads of sweet raisin, cherry and brown sugar. Feel is very sticky. Taste is heavy sweet with a very long finish. Good stuff!

Color caramelo oscuro con espuma beige. Aromas de frutos rojos, frutos confitados y licor. En boca es dulce con toques nuevametne de frutas confitadas. El alcohol (en esta versión 10.5%, no 11%) hace acto de presencia de forma cálida y agradable. Excelente.

Bouteille de 750 mL (2012), consommée un an plus tard après réfrigération. Robe assez foncée. Goût dominant de malts rôtis, de moindre mesure de banane, de caramel. Agréable en bouche. Se mesure aux autres "Grande Cuvée".
On tap. Pours a dark brown with light head. Aromas of sweet roasted malts, light chocolate, and grass/grain. Flavors are similar though richer with additional sugar and alcohol notes. Nice.

750 ml bottle in a tulip 

Aroma : dark fruit , sugar, alcoohol 

Appearance : pour a brown red translucent liquid , with little or no head, very little lacing

Taste : red fruit, caramel, banana and alcohol 

Palate : medium body with little carbonation

Overall : Not a bad sample of a weizenbock far from the best on my opinion aventinus

Pours copper with a large head.
Nose shows booze, rum, raisins, treacle and bready melanoidin notes. Potent...
Very sweet flavours, more bready notes, golden syrup, soft booze and raisins. Very drinkable.
Could use a slightly more syrupy body.

750 mL Bottle (2011 vintage). Pours a murky, deep chestnut color, thin coffee ice cream colored head, not much retention. Nose is kinda boozy, with some oxidization, woody port wine notes (especially as it warms up), dried fruit (dates and figs), caramel, molasses, vanilla. Mouth is medium bodied, creamy and sweet and sticky, slightly warm, dates and figs, toffee, apple cider, grass, vanilla -- notably missing the banana and cloves that other weizenbocks Ive enjoyed display. Overall, a little sweeter than I care for, and the oxidization is noticeable, but still an alright beer. Ive found that Trois Mousquetaires is a decent brewery that doesnt disappoint despite the occasional flaws.

Paid $10.75 @ Winooski Beverage Warehouse. Vintage is 2011 at 10 % ABV. Deep ruby color or some may say a mahogany wood color, very small head with retention. Nose is real interesting. First impression is apple cider/ vinegar with note of raisins and yeast. Flavor is really nice caramel malt with apples and raisins upfront with a hint of oak and prune in the backend. Hints of molasses. Sweet but not cloying. ABV is thoroughly hidden. Wonder what this is like young? After 2 plus years this is really damn nice to sip.

Pours a clear ruby red with a thin off-white head that thins to nothing quickly. Bubbles rising to the surface. Big alcohol legs. Aroma is sweet with a touch of syrup, alcohol and fruits.Taste is sweet with a sweet, warm, alcohol aftertaste. Low to medium body with a medium high carbonation. Bubbly, fuzzy mouth feel. A really nice brew. Nice and warming. Would be nice in.the winter.

Bottle. Pours dark brown with a thick brown head that disappears a bit too fast leaving no lacing. Nose is burnt sugar and molasses. Fairly rich full bodied, sweet, oily, soft carbonation and with a long sticky sweet finish. Hides the alcohol well but something is off.

Fairly sweet flavor with caramel and banana. Full body, low carbonation. The balance improves as it warms. Worth a try.

(2012 bottle aged 9mo) Pours a clear medium red-brown with a light tan froth which faded quickly without lace. The aroma is boozy, with raisins, caramel, candied fruit, banana esters, a light tropical fruit (papaya?) characer and some woody, musty notes. Refrigerated 75 cl brown bottle poured into a tulip. Pours medium brown with small light brown head. Little lacing, medium body, low carbonation, and roasted malt, banana, and booze aroma. Taste roasted, banana, and molasses.
750 ml bottle poured into a Trappist glass. Aroma is very alcohol laden. Tastes of dark fruits, molasses, caramel, walnuts. Big on the palate. Glad it tastes much better than it smells.

UPDATED: JUL 12, 2013 Bouteille de 750 ml, 8,99$ chez IGA. Arôme de banane, caramel et fruits confis. Couleur brune foncée et aucune effervescence. Goût d?alcool relativement prononcé. À partager entre amis, on se lasse après une pinte mais hmmmm une délicieuse pinte!

Couleur brune, voilée. Nez de vin fortifié, de fruits confits, dabricots, et de rhum brun. En bouche, cest liquoreux. Les abricots et le sucre bruns sont prédominants. Cest puissant... Certainement à partager! Personnellement, dans le contexte où on men a offert un verre, je me suis vite lassé...

Vintage 2011. 750ml bottle, caged & corked.  Rusty Brown color, light rusty head.  Ugh, heavy booze nose.  Smells stronger than any BarleyWine Ive had.  Dark fruit smells, as it warms.  Very boozy.  Tastes if honey, dark fruits, sweet fruit sugars.  Mostly a dark honey mead character.  (3729)
de couleur brun avec peu de mousse.on a des arome de banane et erable au gout sucre de erable avec un  gout de banane avec un gout d alcool en fin bouche (rate 84)
Zéro effervescence mais très savoureuse. Quelques années de plus ne lui feront pas de tort...

750 ml bottle from TheEpeeist! Nose is light yeasty banana, candi sugar, golden raisins, and a musty cheese note. Lightly hazy brown with a small beige head. Flavor is yeasty, lightly sweet, a light peppery note, and fruity toffee ending. As Maxwell Smart would say "Very interesting"

750ml bottle.  10.5%.  Pours ruby with a one finger tan head.  Aromas of raisin, wood notes, light molasses, alcohol, faint papaya.  Full bodied, and sweet, with fruity malt notes, maple, plum, white wine notes, mild bitterness and spice in the finish.  The beer equivalent of ice wine.  Rich, and delicious.

750 ml bouchon liège, peluso. 10%. Brune foncée brumeuse, peu de mousse qui disparait vite. Sent le chocolat, les fruits confits et un peu de torréfaction. Goute sucrée, sirop de chocolat, fruits confits. Carbonation en bouche moyenne. On goute l'alcool, ce qui est un peu normal à 10%.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bière rouge-brune, vieillie un an en bouteille.
Nez liquoreux, touche végétale.
Ronde sur le palais, notes de cerise et de fruits à coque. Sucrée, capiteuse, alcool présent mais discret.
750ml bottle. Pours a brown/tan colour with generous head. Theres a bit of everything it seems in the taste: caramel, maple syrup, fruits... Very nice!

750ml bottle poured into snifter.  Pours a nice copper/brown with a generous 3 finger thick head.  Aroma is yeasty (think banana as some belgians), a bit woody also.  Taste is pretty sweet, with a maple syrup profile, caramel, dried fruits and maybe a bit of vanilla.  Mouthfeel is delightful!  Low carbination, slick/slightly oily texture.  Finish is very slightly astringent/acidic with some sugar in the background (which is pretty rare).  Overall, a very very good brew from Trois Mousquetaires!  I have simply never been deceived by them.  The 10.5% abv is simply not perceptible at all...and treacherous!  I simply love this brew!  My 2nd favorite after their Baltic porter.

Brassin de 2011. Au nez, elle libère des odeurs de bois, de cuir et de fruits confits. Belle robe rouge foncée, opaque. A définitivement des arômes animales qui viennent se mêler à des fruits secs (raisins et canneberges) et du sucre dorge en fin de bouche. Savoureuse, complexe, elle nest cependant pas ma préférée de la série Grande Cuvée. Elle demeure très agréable.
Pours tan/brown with off-white head.  Aroma has some coffee, and fruit.  Taste has some spicy caramel.  Smooth drinking.

2011 Vintage:
Pours nearly clear, brown with a small tan head.
Aroma of wood, dark fruit, blackened banana.
Flavour is thick malt, roasted nuts, caramel.
Very rich, nice blending, smooth alcohol feel.
Apple peel....
Most enjoyable.

Production date 15/10/2012 with a 10.5% ABV. Pours a clean rich copper-amber colour with a beige head that is medium, bubbly-fizzy, has average retention, but not much lace. Wheat nose at first pour with some caramel malts. Then some dark fruits come out (plums, raisins) with notes of toffee, coffee and a little sourness. The taste is not as strong as one would think a of high alcohol beer like this one. Dark fruits, burnt sugars, hints of bananas and apples with very mild nuts and hop in the finish. Not much carbonation, medium-to-full bodied with no burning at all. Near the end, the brew becomes hazy and more coffee notes appear in the scent. Decent Weizenbock that is a little mild (and not sure about the sourness - infection ?), but might get better with age (as they recommend aging 3-5 years).

UPDATED: MAR 19, 2014 2014 Re-rate. Bottle. Cloudy amber body, small orange head, good retention. Aroma of figs, caramel, dried apricots, heavy on the yeast, apples and spices. Taste is on the sweet side: lots of caramel, tons of yeast, alcohol, dried apricots, berries liquor, figs. Heavy and oily. No changes. 3.7/5*


2012. 750ml bottle. Pours a cloudy amber-orange body, very decent creamy orange head, even if it was chilled to a very low temperature, retention could be better on the other hand. A fresh aroma: caramel, yeast, fresh grass, dried apples. Taste dominated by a yeast/caramel mix, maple syrup, herbal hops, banana and dried fruits. A late heat wave. Medium body, flat carbonation. Would be interesting taste an aged bottle. 3.7/5*
Fitting strong dark wheat beer for Christmas.dinner at.home. Strong malty sweet notes, nice yeast and bananas.
Bottle (2011).  Boozy port and prune aroma.  Hazy brown with moderate head.  Sweet prune malt and alcohol flavor.  Nice body.  Not bad - not a typical Weizenbock but pretty good.
Bottle. Vinous boozy cherry and wood aroma. Reminds me a bit of cream sherry.  Clear deep chestnut with a small beige head. Sweet oaky cherry and boozy flavor.  Medium body, light carbonbation

Bottle (750 ml). Hazy brown with a small beige head and some lacing. Aroma is of malt, nuts, roasted malt and dark fruits. Taste is malty with nuts, roasted malt, dark fruits and mineral notes. Medium to full body. Alcohol is present. Interesting Weizenbock but nothing worth revisiting.

Édition 2012. Odeurs subtil de prunes et de bananes. Des saveurs de caramel, fruits noirs et banane avec des notes dérables et une très douce douce amertume. WOW, encore meilleur que lédition  2011. Une bière de grande qualité à conserver dans votre cellier.
Bouteille de 750ml, robe cuivré, arôme de sucre caramélisé, goût de banana et caramel à lérable.

750ml bottle from 2012, pretty sure this was 10.5%. Dark mahogany with a nice light brown head. Very sweet malt with some overripe fig, butterscotch, light spice and then more malt. Moderate body and carbonation, quite sweet and grows too much so with the malt overwhelming everything apart from the booze and sweetness. Once small glass was enough.
2011. Very little  hop character. Nice sweet malt aroma. Great balance of malts, slight chocolate and raisin/prune taste. Moderate level of carbonation. A very good beer.

750ml bottle. 2012 10.5%ABV. pours dark ruby/brown with a frothy off-white head. Aroma of fruit and spice. Powerful and full of flavour with some wheat like character. flavour is fairly sweet and syrupy. Exceeded expectations

Bottle from LCBO. Pours a deep ruddy brown with a thin off-white head. The aroma is lovely. Rich fig and date fruitiness with a little bit of light wheaty spiciness. Rich and cocoaish with a little bit of chewiness. Toasted malt, banana and brown sugar behind the plums and clove spiciness. A fairly rich and sweet brew but it isnt cloying at all - I think Id like it a little bit dryer, but its pretty nice nonetheless. Slightly alcoholic with a touch of peppery flavour on the back.

750 mL Bottle. Deep clear ruby body with a frothy-bubbly pale beige head that settles to a foamy film. Aroma of raisins, prunes, and other dark fruits, a yeasty cookie dough accent, subtle notes of butterscotch and banana, and a certain floral sharpness to it. Rich complex flavor although a bit sweet for my liking; definitely "wheaty", a syrupy sweetness something between maple and treacle along with dark fruits and very ripe banana, a yeast bite with the rich sweetness in the aftertaste, and a long syrupy ripe bananas and dates  with an almost wine-like "burn" finish. I would re-visit this one more for its complexity than for an encore so I give it all the bonus points possible here.

Old rate: September 9, 2012; 10% abv, 750 mL bottle, tumbler, BTL: some time in 2011.

Aroma of malty breads, toffee, raisins and molasses. Pours a thick, deep brown with tan health. Some light carbonation in visible. Tastes of sweet breads, molasses followed by a blend of spice and sweet booze. Smooth mouthfeel, luxurious even. The light carbonation cuts through nicely. Goes down with the boozy bite. Great blend of flavours but a bit too sweet. Cloying almost. Still good.

750mL bottle from the lcbo.  Two fingers of tan head, rapidly dissipated.  Caramel, bit of spice of the nose.  Medium body not much visible carbonation but very lively in the mouth.  Big caramel, raisin sweetness, gives way to a slightly sour (cherries?) / bready finish.  Wouldve like a bit more of the grain to come through but oh well, still an amazing beer.

750 mL bottle.  Pours a cloudy mahogany color with a thin tan head, dissipated quickly.  Bready yeasty aroma, a little toasted nut and stewed fruit. Sweet for the style, medium full bodied with low carbonation, coating on the palate with a sour finish.  Fig, raisin, pineapple and banana here, a little grain flavor and malty.  More goodies from LTM.

It pours auburn with ruby highlights; the head is beige and mousse-like. The aroma has notes of: lemon -zest, barnyard funk, yeast, figs, and alcohol. The taste is medium-heavy sweet that finishes the same: there are notes of: pepper, figs, candied apricots, alcohol, and pumpernickel bread. The palate is medium-full bodied, thick, very low carbonation, oily, and long finish. Overall, ssssguuud.

0.75l bottle from LCBO, served in a tulip. Pours an opaque brown with a tiny beige head. Aroma: Caramel, raisins, bananas, hints of nuts, vanilla. Really nice mix. Palate: Thick bodied, slightly oily, very fizzy, long, clean finish. Taste: Very sweet. Really nice sweetness though. The alcohol taste is slightly there. Really really awesome beer.

Poured in wheat beer glass. 2 finger head,red to light,orangy amber red away and extremly carbinated. Smell from bottle is chocolate & bananna
Smell from glass is like sweet fruit,gummy,malty. Taste as I take it in on every sip its fruity like plums n other dark fruit n a little sweet. kinda like a Belgin quad. Then every sip that is swallowed starts with some warmth in belly and then I taste chocolate with a sprinkle of hop bitterness and then it gos into a bannana bread taste. Truthully it taste nothing like any kind of wheat beer. BIG bottle and boozy % will fill ya up & fuck ya up 8.5/10

750mL bottle from LCBO.  Standard "weizenbock" aroma, but better than usual - banana, vanilla, spices.  Taste has the same characteristics as the aroma, but with some added brown sugar.  Its quite sweet, but quite good.

750 mL bottle shared by kevinsenn. Smells beery. With caramel and dark fruits, particularly apples. Its pretty damn sweet... Almost too much.

Very little head with very dark red body.

Flavour is rich and beautiful at first, but its richness turns to a somewhat cloying sweetness pretty quickly. No hops at all, just fruity sugars. Too damn sweet.

2012 bottle from the LCBO, in my 1L stein, because thats how I roll. Pours a hazy brown with a good amount of tan head that dissipates fairly quickly. Smell is sweet caramel, dark fruits, wheat, and maybe a bit of vanilla. Palate is on the heavy side of medium bodied, and has some palate covering yet not too strong carbonation. Taste is really great, a bit sweet and fruity at first, but then gets a bit more bitter rounding out the taste before getting some more smooth sour/sweet/bitter taste that lingers for quite a while. Really excellent weizen bock.

2011 750 c&c shared by Marcus. Pours very dark brown with a tan head. Aroma suggests dark wheat in a barrel. Marvelous aroma. Full bodied. Flavor is oak barrel, brown sugar, a bit vinous. Finishes on the sweet side. Extremely tasty.

2011 Bottle from Healthy Spirits. Pours dark brown with a nice beige head and a treacle and alcohol aroma. There is a delicious fruit and molasses flavor. It tastes like its brandy barrel aged, but there is no evidence of that. A great sipper.

750mL bottle, 2011 vintage.  Poured cola brown with a creamy beige head.. set up nicely in the glass.  The aroma was very assertive, with rich, brandy-soaked dark fruits and raisins joined by aged caramel and molasses.. almost a cognac burn on the back of the nose.. good stuff in there, but a touch too hot.  The flavor found peppery and vinous boozage on the tip of the tongue, with warm chocolate, molasses, and chewy dark bread rolling in behind.. dark fruit bitterness, cloves, and black pepper around.. finished spicy and belly-warming with rich vinous and yeasty character.  Heavy-bodied with moderate-plus carbonation on the palate.. a little syrupy on the middle.. boozy, but there were enough sugars to balance.. I enjoyed this.

De couleur brun-rouge, bourgogne, assez foncé, une mousse typique, toutefois éphémère, la coiffe. on a quà la remuer pour quelle réapparaisse. Un nez de fruits rouge, de fruits séchés, de blé, dorge et de malt font office dodeurs. En bouche, cest sucré, comme si on buvait un bonbon. Des traces dherbes et davoine se font sentir à loccasion, au travers lalcool qui lui, sait se faire discret (dailleurs, jai la version 2011 à 10%). La texture est sirupeuse, parsemée dune légère amertume en arrière-goût et belle sensation de chaleur lorsquelle descend. (390-081012)

On tap at the gingerman. Pours a reddish brown. Smells of super sweet cherries. You can also smell tthe booze hopping out of the glass. Tastes of raisin, cheries and slight anise. Very tasty but potent. A whole glass of this is going to be a little much.

UPDATED: NOV 30, 2012 750mL from Broue Ha Ha, Gatineau.  Colour is that of nice pumpkin pie filling and nearly as opaque.  Tastes like the victory of  taking down thirtysome of Cardinal Richelieus gardes.

750 ml bottle (2011 vintage - 10%) from Premier Wine and Spirits (Halifax).  Pours a murky dark orange-brown with decent-sized, lasting light tan head.  Aroma is dark fruit, treacle, brown sugar and toffee.  Flavour is sweet caramel, brown sugar, raisin, fig and molasses.  Silky mouthfeel.  Very nice.

12oz draught 
10.0% ABV 
Bar Volo (Toronto, Ontario, Canada) 
September 6, 2012 
The beer poured a dark chocolate brown with a very thin head despite plenty of effervescence.  The aroma was dark fruit, mollases, some banana, and spices.  The mouthefeel was full bodies with medium carbonation.  The flavour was sweet malt, molasses, and a definite hint of alcohol.  A better tasting beer than the aroma and appearance would indicate.

Bouteille 750ml. 2011. Couleur brun un peu trouble, mousse beige assez dense. Arôme de blé, de grains, de fruits confits et dalcool. Goût de sucre brun, de fruits confits avec une belle amertume en fin de bouche. Texture riche avec une faible carbonation.
Draft. Clear maroon color, small tan edge head. Aroma of nutella. Taste is bittersweet chocolate, hazelnut, booze. Decent.

Draft.  Small beige head, lightly hazed dark brown body.  Aroma is moderately sweet, caramel, light smoke.  Taste is sweet, caramel, some orange, light alcohol burn.  Sticky medium-full body, low carbonation.

Pours a cloudy red with decent lacing and some head retention. Aroma is sweet sugarcane and toffee. Taste follows through with a lot of sweetness that goes down a bit one-dimensional. Liked the saint bock weizenbock I had much better than this. I can appreciate this, but Ill probably avoid the high price bottle in Quebec in favor of the maibock or baltic porter. Tap at volos.
biere tres maltée reconfortante par temps froid. parfaite devant un feu .malt caramel petite touche chocolatée café petit gout fumée subtile
Pretty wheaty, not too similar to other bocks, but it was very flavourful and it was nice to drink, it was a good offering

Hiver 2010
Tasted on 3/21/12 from a corked and caged 750mL bottle obtained in a trade.  Pours a deep, nearly opaque, mahogany with a thin, smooth tan head that leaves a thin collar of lace.  The nose is sweet clover honey with some dark bread notes, a touch of caramelized banana, and a ton of caramel overall.  The flavor is the same sweet, dark bread clover honey with some cereal, and tons of caramel, with just a touch of banana.  The body is full with light carbonation and a long dark bread and honeyed finish.
Cloudy, muddy oak with a high carbonation. No head. syrup, malt aroma. rich syrup flavour. Malt brown sugar.Smooth yet tangy finish.
But comme dessert avec un gateau au framboise! caramel , petits fruits et alcool en bouche!! tres bonne!

pours dark walnut brown, almost no head, minor CO2 ringed retention, runny lacing, some CO2 streams near the perimeter. Strong prunes on the nose. Starts off with medium CO2 bubbled carbonation, transitions into 7/10 sweet fruity prune & dried red fig flavours, followed by a bittersweet chocolate finish. Medium-high complexity, medium-high depth, medium length, good transitions, good carry. An interesting fruity dark beer, but too sweet for me to enjoy again.

750ml corked bottle pours a dark amber color with a 3 finger light beige head that leaves some nice lacing.  Aroma is caramel malts with some faint hops, spices and yeast.  Taste is caramel malty sweetness with the spices and yeast and a mild hoppy bitter finish.  There is a slight warming from the alcohol and a medium to heavy body with some nice carbonation.  Overall, a nice somewhat complex ale which is very enjoyable on a cold winter day.

Un nez de raisins confits et de grains rôtis, les sucres sont annoncés dès le départ. En bouche cest très soyeux avec une effervescence soutenu qui rend bien service. Lagencement de saveurs me fait penser à un gâteau aux fruits avec un riche glaçage au caramel suivi dune longue finale cassonade/mélasse accompagné dune subtile amertume au fond du palais.

Bottle @ Dans. Hazy, reddish brown appearance with a tan head. Very sweet toffee, rich caramel malty aroma. Very rich toffee, caramel malty, somewhat spicy, rich toffee flavor. Im a little disappointed.

Deep brown with ruby highlights. Aroma is molasses, berries, malts, vinegar, booze, and earthy hops. Full bodied. Flavor is right in line with aroma with a light spice and less booze. Good stuff this one.

(Bottle) Pours dark reddish brown with a nougat coloured head. The aroma holds vinegar up front with undertones of caramel, bread, cardboard, cream and light earthy hops. The flavour is medium sweet, light bitter and tiny acidic. Caramel, wheat, bread, light fruits and a whisper of hops. The mouthfeel is round and sticky with a light carbonation. Lingering sticky caramel finish alongside a whisper of hops.  Medium bodied.

jadore cette bière.  Une odeur de fruit confits (okay, létiquette a aidé!).  Belle robe rouge vin.  Le goût est divin; sucré, fruité, épicé.  Seul reproche; le palais est un peu trop gazéifié à mon goût.  Une bière que je recommande pour accompagné un repas (presque nimporte quoi!  Mais surtout de la viande avec une sauce, préférablement un peu sucré).

750 ml bottle. Pours a nice, hazy amber brown with a pale orange white head. Smells fruity. Tastes fruity, caramel, brown sugar. Slight crème brûlée finish, maybe also some spices. Body is average, creamy, carbonation is low to average. Quite good!

This Weizenbock pours out a beautiful dark brown with hues of light amber. A finger of yellowish head leaves thick rings of sticky lacing. The nose is wheaty and extremely well malted with a hint of brown sugar and candied fruits. A warm alcohol and a typical German yeast spice. Notes of clove, vanilla, allspice and banana. The taste is quite strong to start off with a sweet fruity middle, a huge wheat malt and toffee biscuits. A lovely riaisin and prune candied fruit. The finish has a lingering spice and a powerful alcohol presence. This tastes similar to a Dubbel style with an intense wheaty malt and German yeast spice. The 11% alcohol does not go unnoticed in the taste. Full bodied, wheaty and big chewy malts with a lingering strong finish. Overall, a great Weizenbock with a ton of flavor!

Yet more notes from DLD to fill out ratings at the start of a month. Bottle lists 2011 vintage and a 10.3 abv. Pours a very dark beer color. A dark bock with a thin ring of foam around the edge. Smell has some alcohol and a little fruit to it. Taste is VERY thick with malts. Cant pick up the usual weizen bock spiciness. Just very malty and tasty, with not a lot of hop to it. Sweet.

From tap at La Succursale, 10.2%. Pours dark brown with a thick, tan and creamy head. Aroma is roasted malty and breadish. Sweet, fruity, wheaty and light overripe banana. Mild bitterness and slight caramelish. Roasted and dark malty. Light bitter and caramelish finish.

Bottle,10.3% ABV. Hazy mahogany with a fluffy beige head. Aroma of toffee, stwed prunes, dried bananas, grass, mace. Chewy. Taste is very sweet with toffee, dried and stewed fruit, light spices. A faint wheaty tang is there too, moreso at the end. The sweetness is cleaned up a bit at the end, which is a good thing. Theres quite a lot of bitterness there but its buried pretty deep. Heavy but not quite as boozy as Id expected, although theres some fortified wine character there. Doesnt get cold enough in town for this to really work in Australia, but I can see this hitting the spot where it does.

Sample from bottle.  Pours a cloudy brown color with a medium sized brown head. The aroma has a large amount of sweet brown sugars, malts and a moderate amount of ripe dark fruit.  The flavor is very similar, with brown sugars, prunes and a big sweet malt.  This is rather bold in its presentation and all of the pieces dont always agree, but on o cold winter night, this would surely do the trick.
Tasted at Seaport Beer festival. More earthy notes and has a ketchup chip aroma. Has a creamy note on the palate but taste really cereal like.

Misty red brown pour medium carbonation biege frothy good sized head with aromas yeast grain spice floral overtones burnt malts flavours nutty caramel sugary toffee raw sugar clove syrup once into this bock it smooths out mildest of bitter finish strong alcohol but hardly noticeable strong malt tastes dark rich sweet smooth bitter perhaps too sweet

Pours a murky brown/amber colour with tan head. Really earthy on the nose (which Im noticing seems to be a trademark with these guys) with lots of cereal grain and malt vinegar with a hickory smoke edge. Sweet and earthy on the palate with grain and a smoky edge.

Dark reddish brown colour with streaky film of head. Heavy aroma of sweet pit fruits, prune. Maltiness is made present with a warm yet smooth alcohol presence. Overall a very enjoyable beer but not my ideal Weizen.

Im Antrunk baut sich ein schwaches Alkoholaroma auf, malzig, für 10% aber sehr mild. Der Mittelteil ist ebenfalls mild, etwas fruchtig, dazwischen immer wieder alkoholisch. Ab dem Mittelteil ist der Hopfen ein wichtiger Bestandteil, ohne das die Malzigkeit geringer werden würde. In Ordnung, aber etwas eintönig. 	 
Test vom 4.11.2007, Gebinde: Glasflasche 	Noten: 10,10,10,12,10,11 - 10,70

Bière de couleur noisette, aux reflets roux.  Peu de col ou de dentelle au verre.  On y note des arômes boisés de cerises et dalcool.  Très légère amertume pour tout le sucre quelle offre.  En bouche, on note une effervescence moyenne, un corps bien charpenté et une texture huileuse.

Pour auburn with a khaki head. Aroma, cherry, dark fruit, sweet, brown sugar, spice. Taste super sweet, dark fruit, cherries, wheat, spice, clove. MF full slightly oily body decent carb. Good beer but a tad to sweet sipper/sharer.

Dark cloudy brown with a light white head. Smells of caramel malts with a hint of cherries. Toaty caramel malts make the main taste here, so not as complex as I might like. I still feel that drowning in it wouldnt be overly bad.

I dont understand what other reviewers are saying about tasting complex flavours. All I can taste is sugar. Very sweet wheat bock, nothing like a German wheat bock. Well maybe like a German wheat bock if you added a couple of spoons of sugar to each glass.

On tap. A beastly brew for sure. Pours a murky brown color with a medium brown head. The aroma is massive; sweet brown sugars, malts and soem fruit just jump out at you- warning that this will get you smashed. The flavor is just as robust; warm bordering on hot, brown sugars, prunes, a heavy sweet malt. A strong brew for the Quebec winters for sure. Nice.

Bottle. great brew. very rich and very complex. Dark fruit.. rich caramels and a tinge of spice. Dark nutty aroma and slight roasty taste. Brown sugar is the primary sweetness. very strong with well masked alcohol.

(750ml bottle) Purchased at Cook Street Liquor Store for $13.20. Pours a lofty, beige head atop a strong red-brown body. Right of the bat - sniff, sniff - this has a lot of the aroma of Trois Pistoles: plum, smooth brandy and vanilla. Great ruby plums swirl the palate, the heightened alcohol (10.3%) is less apparent than that of Trois Pistoles (9%). Some earthy undertones. A wonderful, wonderful beer. Unfortunately its twice the price of Trois Pistoles here in British Columbia ($5.99) or Id be alternating between the two regularly.

bottle shared. Hazy dark brown small white head. A: dark fruits, dark caramel, intense licorice. F: full body finish is sweet and long nice texture its close to sticky. O: Really good like all of their special series.
Pours a cloudy brown colour with a descend size head which dissipates quickly. the aroma is sweet malts , cloves, the taste is very sweet alc. molasses and dried fruit with a dry finish.
Bouteille 750 ml. 10,3%. Couleur brune un peu brouillée. Mousse beige. Arôme de céréale, blé et fruits mûrs. Goût de terre, chocolat, levure et alcool. Finale sans amertume. Bonne.
Stong aroma of caramel with a hint of coffee. Heavy sweetness. Full body with a bit of an oily texture. Top notch beer from one of the great breweries in the country.

Pours a beautiful muddy brown with plenty of beige head. Aroma of fermented malts mashed in with grass and swampwater. Flavour is heavy barley syrup mixed with bière de garde grass and a huge alcoholic finish. Really, who are they kidding - this stuff has "malt liquor" written all over it but theyve added a few fancy French accents to make people think its something else, aside from major suckage. Dudes, I aint fooled.

2010 750 ml bottle. Dark brown color with brown head. Aroma of caramalised malts and fruits. Taste is mainly dark fruits, caramel and cacao. The alcohol presence is not well hidden, yet it is very sweet and easy to drink. Got to say I expected a little bit more complexity. Still,  its a good one.

2009 Vintage. Jotted down this: deep brown, clear with a small medium tan head, goes right to a skim. Smell: fairly sweet and lots of caramel, powdery chocolate, prunes and dark fruit. Taste-o: faint alcohol if any, nice spice, fruit cake, nougat and a bit of brown sugar. Seemed a bit only but no alcohol and a nice finish made this a lot better than I thought it would be.

Bottle 75cl from mondial de la bière. A dark beer with nice brownish head. Smell has nice wheat notes as well as caramel like smell. Aroma is intense on roasted malt, wheat, caramel, alcohol is present and do heat quickly. This syrupy beer is very nice and complex, on fruit like dry grapes, licorice, prune, also near to weizeneisbock. Finish remains chocolate and dark malt notes with dry prune and cherry aftertaste. A well done beer.

UPDATED: NOV 4, 2012 Wheat, but moreover ripened fruits, dark fruits. Fine caramels. Pours dark brown, almost black. Medium to heavy body. Good head and retention. Much more than respectable weizenbock...!

Superb dark beer with a wonderful complexity!

To my experience, left alone for two years in a dark cool place, really make its caracteristics come out!  It becomes almost like a porto, heavenly!

Unaged, its a complex mix between macerated fruits, slighly nutty aroma and a hint of herbs

Bottle, shared with Rockley. Pours a deep hazy brown with golden highlights and a thick creamy light golden head that shows eternal retention. Aroma is sweet, brown sugar and dark fruits. Flavours of creme brulee, fig paste, sugar bread. Silky, rich mouthfeel. Loved this!
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Looks monstrously dark red brown with lighter brown-gold highlights. Medium dark tan cap. Aroma is like spice kola citrus and concord grape. Taste replays aromas with bold port tones underneath, unbelievable grapey tasting beer.  Dark fruit and warming alcohol reliably in balance. Finish is like brandied cherries and lemon peel with some spice. Fantastic beer, beyond expectations.

Bottle from 16th St. Liquor in West Vancouver. Pours a dark reddish brown with little head that vanished shortly after pouring. Aroma is cola sweet with plum, tobacco, rich malt. Taste is wonderfully deep with port like fruit notes, roasted chestnut, figs, dates, alcohol is warming but not overbearing. Mouthfeel is thick and slightly carbonated. Finish has notes of brandied cherries. Wonderfully complex and rewarding. Excellent.

Bottle, pours dark brown with a red tinge. Aroma of fruit, caramel malt, toffee and alcohol. Flavour is extremely complex - candied fruits: plum, raisin, figs; and caramel malts. Palate is extremely chewy, almost syrupy, very sticky, with a smooth finish that hides the alcohol. An exquisite brew.

Bottle corked 750 ml gift from Doug 
Aroma :  noticeable alcohol , bit earthy , ripe prunes and Hungarian plum. 7+ 
Appearance: mid hazed dark amber brown. Lighter top. Visible carbonation.
Flavour and Palate: full bodied. Smooth clean sweetness , brown sugar with wheat silky character. Alcohol smooth , slightly dry yet well build in whole set up. Candy sugar finishing. Fun to have well till you wake up next day at least. Very sold extreme wheat ale.

En bouteille.  Brassin Hiver 2010.  Bière brune foncée qui propose au nez un amalgame de grains maltés moyennement rôtis, de fruits foncés et macérés comme le raisin, la cerise noire et la mûre.  Présence chatouilleuse du 11%.  En bouche, retour des principales caractéristiques découvertes dans les arômes avec une intensification au niveau des fruits foncés : goût de gelée de raisin et de confitures de cerise et de pruneau.  Sous le palais, le liquide offre aussi une réponse moyenne damertume à la douceur sucrée du malt.  La délicate lourdeur de lalcool combiné aux notes fortes de raisins donne aussi un aspect très liquoreux au liquide.  En résumé, bière au corps expansif assez dangereuse.

750ml bottle from Le Gobelet. drank out of weizen glass, pours a murky brown with an off white head that quickly fades away. aroma is all dark fruits, malts, and of course alcohol. the alcohol is quite over powering in both the nose and the taste. maybe its just the style, but i didnt enjoy this one very much.

On tap @Vices et Versa.

 Aroma is an enticing  toasted malt, and fine chocolate, deep brown, tiny tan head. Flavour is an epic hit of roasted malt, chocolate, toast, woody and nutty too. Full bodied, perfectly balanced, lovely bitterness, terribly easy to drink even at 11%.Sensational!!

Bottle Murky prune-colored ale with a small, creamy, khaki head. Great retention. Smells sweet, vinous, roasted and lactic  infection, I fear. Full-bodied with flimsy carbonation. Sugary, roasted flavor  akin to a cup of mocha java with about eight spoonfuls of sugar. Only a whisper of acidity. Bittersweet, roasted finish. Not infected after all. Kudos to MartinT for providing the bottle!
Poors a dark beer with some plum colors. Very strong aroma of fruits. A caramel taste, a little bit sour, with fruits and alchool. Will get better if aged.

Trois Mouquetaires is one of my favourite breweries in Quebec and this is why.  Aroma is malt, sharp alcohol and dark purple fruits.  Pours a plum dark brown with a minimal white head.  Taste is purple fruits, malt and the bitterness of alcohol.  Well balanced, fairly complex flavours that fills the palate.  Very enjoyable beer that Ill look forward yearly.

50 ml bottle from Marche Jovi, served at cellar temperature in a tulip glass. DE 24/09.
App.:  Very deep brown-mahogany with a moderate light tan head.
  
Aroma:  Slightly tangy, minty licorice, some molasses, some wheat, wet hay, bright dried fruits, caramel, brown sugar, figs, some dark chocolate, malt all over the place.
  
Palate:  Medium+ body, moderate effervescence.
  
Flav.:  More dark dried fruits than the nose, figs, apricots, milk chocolate, plenty of alcohol, some vanilla, rum, vinous, slightly salty and savoury, so much raisin; sweet with enough bitterness and a fair bit of warming alcohol. 

This is a nice example of a big beer.

750ml. bottle, 2009 vintage. Dark red brown with a nice brownish head. Lots of fruity esters, cassonade and some tar dominates the aromas. Full body, alcohol well hidden, warming the throat nicely, loads of dried fruits on the palate lasting trough the finish. Really great example of a strong weizenbock. A real treat for lager lovers.
211109 Tasting with Ungdomsklubben. Pours a slightly hazy brown. Sweet and malty with hints of port. Also hints of residual sugars and fruity yeast esters towards the end. Dry and malty finish.

Bottle at Sunes - Thanks to Mikkel for bringing it to Denmark. Clear dark red/brown - offwhite head. Licorice, alcoholic, raisins, dried fruits, sweetness, brown sugar, bitterness, sticky body. Too alcoholic.

Bottle at Sune.
Clear orange red coloured with a huge off white head.
Sweet and fruity aroma of dried fruits and berries.
Sweet flavour of dried fruits, caramel and liquorice with notes of alcohol.
Sweet and warming alcoholic finish.

750 ml Bottle:  

Clouded chestnut brown with ruby highlights. Puffy beige cap that lasts and laces

Rich and complex with flavors; cocoa, roast, berries, smoke, earthyness dried fruit, tobacco, hrbacious hopping and a long wet complex finish. Like a lighter version of a dark barley wine,

Wonderful winter warmer.

Bottle, brown pour with red coming through. Aroma is choke cherries, wood, and alcohol. Taste is kind of acid, citrusy up front (grapefruit) with a slow change towards roasted malts and bitterness, barn. Long mouthfeel.

Dark ruby pour with a small beige head. Aroma of sweet malts, sherry, alcohol and an odd musty almond. The typical banana esters are nowhere to be found this seems more like a Belgian strong ale with hints of a weizenbock. Weird beer, its not bad it enjoyable, but to me it seems way off the style lines.

750 mL bottle.  Opaque ruby-brown with a large, sticky, short-lived beige head.  Large aroma of dried dark fruit (raisins, dates, prunes), dark fruit, wheat, and caramel.  Flavour is huge, with the dark fruit dominating, along with licorice, alcohol, a little spice, and molasses.  Solid body.  A weaker cousin to Aventinus Eisbock.

0.75 l bottle at PBF. Dark reddish brown color. Plummy, vinous, peppery and perfumed aroma with notes of charcoal and red wine. Plummy, peppery and vinous flavir with hint coffee and charcoal roast. Full bodied oily palate. Warming yet soft. Nice vinous plum character.

Agréable au goût lorsque prise lentement.

http://tangara.forumactif.net/parfum

I really enjoyed this beer.  Pours a dark amber color with a nice beige-tinted head.  Rich aroma flies right out of the bottle after being uncorked; notes of caramel, nuts, molasses and perhaps a hint of woodiness.  Flavor is very well balanced, smooth on the tongue...really nutty with roasted malts.  Finishes a little dry with plenty of aromatic quality after each sip.  Alcohol is disguised very well.  Not too familiar with the style but found this beer to be quite a pleasant experience.

Bottled at PBF.  Cloudy brownish red, rich but brief head. Caramelly nose withsome red berries behind. Sweet with a tart berryish yeast component. Intense brandy-like alcohol with burnt caramelly malt behind. Salty finish.

(Bottled, 0.75l) Muddy brown with a small, tanned head. Aroma of sourish, lightly vinegary malt, some alcohol, dried fruit. Flavor of licorice, lightly roasted malt, vinegary hints, also dried fruitiness and a touch of alcohol. Medium to full body, soft carbonation. Maybe slightly alcoholic, but very nice anyway.

Bottled (PBF, vintage 2009). 
Ruby color, steady small beige head. Caramelly, dark fruits and wheaty aroma. Wineous mouthfeel. Full-bodied. Wheat, caramel, raisins, alcohol. Intensive flavors. Perharps a bit too alcholic almost. Interesting, very different than eg. Aventinus or Vitus.

Bottled. Hazy ambery brown colour, mediumsized beige foamy head. Aroma is alcohol, whear, grass, mild spices, Dark dry fruits as well. Flavour is sweet caramel malts, alcohol and some quite grassy notes. Mild raisins and plum.

Deep hazy ruby-tinted brown coloured body with a dense two centimetre tall head of tan, nicely laced froth. Aroma of wheat, caramel, malt, cherries, pit fruits and some nice nuts. Medium to Full-bodied; Strong assertive malty body with wheat, caramel, oak, vanilla and pit fruits very noticeable. Aftertaste shows a lot of malt, some nuts and a good dose of caramel. Overall, a good strong beer with a lot of character and plenty of good complexity. I sampled this 75 cL bottle purchased at Depanneur Peluso (Bonisoir) in Montreal, Quebec, Canada on 09-April-2009 sample on 03-July-2009 on the Eastern Shore of Virginia.

750ml bottle shared by WeeHeavySD vis trade with boutip/ poured dark brown with off white head. very sweet and malty, sightly sticky finish with good carmel notes, not sure how old the bottle was, but it went down very smooth, no hint of alcohol.

On tap at Brouhaha, aged 6 months. Very dark pour, nearly black, with minimal off white head. Aroma is interesting; spicy, almost a hint of chipotle, along with dark fruity esters and sweet malt. Flavor is intense; dark fruit abound, with heavy spice, malt character, cherry, and brown sugar prevailing as well- very much like a barleywine. Palate is very nice; smooth, and the alcohol sticks brilliantly. Really nice brew.

Dar brown, almost black pour with ruby brown tints and minimal head. Aroma is fruity esters and capsaicin based spice. Caramel and raisin come through as well with hints of citrus. Intense dark fruit and caramel flavors. Chilli notes are ever so noticeable, with roasted malt and brown sugar also prevalent. Wheat malt character is interesting and unique. Very thick and full palate. Perfect amount of carbonation. Very well balanced, and a great example of the style.

Bonus corked and caged 750ml, from boutip, thank you sir!  2009 vintage.  Shared with bikesandbeer and my gf cyn.  Pours deep reddish brown with a thin layer of tan head.  Nose is very sweet and malty.  Taste is sweet, with big toffee rich apple notes.  Yummy big and nicely warming, not hot by any means.

750 ml bottle on mancation at Mondiale 09.  Pours a deep ruby brown with an initial big fluffy head but fades a bit due to the high abv.  Aroma is caramel, nutty, rich toffee, very fruity esters, plum and banana, toffee, light roast and chocolate with spices- phenol, pepper and grassy.  Flavor is sweet, molassess, toffee, brown sugar, banana liquor, plum raisin, light apple, hints of nutty malty chocoalte, hints of roast, prunes, apricot and spice.  Mouthfeel is pretty good- modest carbonation and a good aftertaste.  Not bad for a huge weizenbock.

Brown bottle, 750 ml, purchased at Le Grand Duc on April 11 2009, savoured on May 16 2009; eye: dark caramel, rich, no effervescence, tiny ring of beige head, slight lacing; nose: caramel malt, light alcohol, light fruity, light molasses, brown sugar; mouth: caramel malt, molasses is quite present, alcohol, pepper, dark fruits, a bit of nuts, a bit of ash, brown sugar, finale in caramel malt with a good presence of molasses, medium-full body, lightly bitter, mildly sweet, sticky texture; overall: fine

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille brune, 750 ml, achetée chez Le Grand Duc le 11 avril 2009, savourée le 16 mai 2009; il : caramel foncé, riche, pas deffervescence, petit anneau de mousse beige, très léger dentelle; nez : malt caramel, léger alcool, léger fruité, léger mélasse, cassonade; bouche : malt caramel, mélasse bien présente, alcool, poivre, fruits foncés, un peu de noix, un peu de cendre, cassonade, finale en malt caramel avec bonne présence de mélasse, corps moyen-corsé, légèrement amère, moyennement sucrée, texture collante; en résumé : bien

Bottle of the 2009 vintage from the Marche Atwater in Montreal.  Pours a nice mahogany color with a medium sized light tan head.  Smells sweet and malty, with nice sugary notes a touch of molasses, and a really nice toast note that develops as the beer warms.  Still a bit hot, and alcohol notes appear just about everywhere. Medium bodied with a nice thick amount of malt.  Finishes a little bitter, but still malty, with a bit of dark fruit and chocolate.
Bottle split with Pwn3d and AndyDep. Pours a dark, hazy red. Aroma is plum, brown sugar, nut, and vinegar. Taste is nutty and some slight dark fruit with a sharp alcohol flavor.

Bottle from purchased in Montreal.  Split with DeputyAndy and JRedmond. 2009 11% version.   Nose is brown sugar and walnut.  Mouth is rather complex for your typical Weizenbock..  Dark fruits -cherry, sugar plums, grape and complemented with some warming alcohol. Strong, very good and underrated  4.15
Bottle. Infected bottle. Remnants of what was once a good beer, but overall a drain pour.

Acheté au jovi en format de 750ml et dégusté dans un verre mug. Une chose est certaine, jai hâte de goûter au millésime précédent qui vieilli dans mon cellier. Apparence brun foncé opaque au reflet caramel harmonisant une belle mousse collante au verre à chacune de mes gorgés. Arômes de sel de céleri, de noisette, de mélasse avec une touche de caramel. En bouche, un goût de mélasse, de datte, de figue et de malt avec une légère amertume. Une exellente compagne par journée froide dhiver.

2009 version, 750 ml bottle. Pours brown almost orange, nice head very good looking. A lot of taste but not very much what I like. Lots of alcohol taste. Maybe the timing for that beer was not right but I did not enjoy it a lot. Not even close to the Aventinus which is a top 10 beer for me.

2009 version shared at the KW tasting, courtesy of BeerGeek.  Brown pour, nice white head.  Yeasty aroma, alcohol as well - nice.  Good taste - sharp weizen bock taste, lots of alcohol, lots of malt.  Very good - aventinus like with more carbonation and less complexity.

750 ml bottle, 2009 edition. shared at the KW group tasting at tupalevs. pours ruby with a nice tan head. aroma are sweet yeasty and malty. dark fruit, some chocolate and even hops in the nose. the flavour was quite complex with typical weizen bock flavour playing a background role to the more aggressive roasted malt profile and a huge dose of hops. very interesting interpretaton of the style. it didnt drink like an 11% brew but if it is i wouldnt have a problem putting back all 750ml. thanks for the share KW group!

UPDATED: DEC 4, 2009 Some think the Québécois are solid beer drinkers.  I think that too...  But it does not change the fact that the choice is often a problem here.  We cant get american beers except a few uninteresting ones.  Do you want an Old Milwaukee?  So this beer is the only Weizenbock I ever had with the Aventinus.  Even if high in ABV, the alchool is not that noticeable.  Very fruity and tongue-tingling spices are very obvious, and so is the presence of leafy hops.  Quite complex and more warming than refreshing or easy to drink.  All in all, a pretty enjoyable Extreme brew.

750ml bottle shared at Tupalevs, big thanks to the provider. Pours out a hazy greyish brown. Aroma is not at all what I was expecting, very hoppy, sharp, herbal, sweet and sort of like an Imperial Stout? Weird. Flavour matches up well with toffee, booze, astringency and just a mild hint of wheat. Decent fuller feeling body to it. I was expecting something at least remotely similar to Aventinus, but this could not be any more different. Still seems almost vaguely Imperial Stout like to me for some reason. Quite an interesting one although I have to say I expected more. Im glad to have been able to try it though, as well as another example of an Weizen Bock.

Bottle shared with French Tickler and Pyroziod.  Dark brown, thick brownish head.  Aroma: Soya, molasses, smocky, tereaki sauce and raisins.  Flavor:  wheat grass, molasses, brown sugar, alcoholwith a tast of ash.  Palate: full body with a creamy sticky texture well carbonated.

Dégusté avec Pyrozoid.  Apparence brun foncé avec un tres beau collet beige tres collant.  Arome de sel de celeri, figues, sucre brun,  un peu de sauce soya, sauce teriyaki et clou de girofle.  Bouche tres ronde, malté, bonne présence subtile dalcool avec une finition cremeuse et onctueuse.  Gout de spiruline, caramel, cassonade et le celeri reviens a nouveau.

Bouteille de 750 ml. Dégusté avec french tickler et Agaguk. Biere de couleur brune orangé avec un moyen collet beige tres collant. Odeur de raisins, épices,  sucre brun, un peu fleural et dattes. Gout de blé, sec, un peu de sucre et caramel.
bouteille de 750ml bouchon de liège, bière brune reflets orangés, nez de caramel, sucrée, figues.  maltée, bouche sucrée, longue, chaleureuse, maltée,
Pours a mahogany body with an off white head.  Lots of dark fruits, raisin, figs, and plum alcohol latentent.  A nice spiced character and wheat.  A light nuttiness and caramel as well.  Good stuff.

Pours a nice colour, with a moderate head.  The aroma draw you in of wheat, dark fruit.  The taste is a good full mouthfeel, its rich, nails the style but must it be at 10%? A tad of sourness in some sips, some sips with bitterness too.

Bouteille de 341 ml édition 2006. Nos yeux observent une bière brune très foncée avec des reflets rubis profond et une mousse brunâtre modeste. Notre nez est chatouillé par des arômes de raisins et de prunes confîts ainsi que par des effluves de caramel écossais et d’alcool. À certaine inspiration, des notes de madères, de chocolat et de grain torréfiés sont aussi perceptible. En bouche la bière se fait lourde et moyennement effervescente sur notre pauvre langue qui se fait attaquer de tous les côtés par des flaveurs de sucre brun, de raisins confîts, de dattes, de caramel brulé, de grain torréfié, de chocolat noir et d’alcool. Le tout se termine par une amertume terreuse avec une présence de madère. Merci Sébastien.
20070428  Bottle after TAPNY.  Toasty, lots of burnt sugars, fruit-nut bread notes.  A bit pretzely especially at finish.  Mineral hints.

2007 vintage.  Pours a very dark cherrywood brown color with crimson highlights.  A small, creamy, khaki colored head settles to a thin film, leaving spotty lacing in its wake.  Aromas were rich and malty, showing tons of dark raisons, figs, and dates, with a good amount of cinnamon spice and sweet, caramel malts.  Flavors were sweet, fruity, and slightly roasty.  Chocolate joins the caramel, as does a touch of hazelnut.  Raison and other dark fruits again play a huge role.  Nearly full bodied and very smooth, this brew has a great mouthfeel save for the overly sticky finish.  Awesome all around brew.  I wish I could get more.

Bottle, thanks lagsga!
Beige head over dark brown beer. Burned suager, full malty sweetness, a warming alcohol edge balances the sweetness.

Medium yellowish brown hread. Hazy deep amber barely translucent body with carbonation. Intense chocolatey roasty caramel aroma with oily, bready notes. Round and harmonic. Deep sweet roasty fruity caramel and chocolate taste with fruity bready notes. Harmonic. Some alcohol heat is noticeable, unsurprisingly. Very full-bodied. Maybe a bit on the sweet side, but saved by the alcohol from becoming cloying. Some bitterness is noticeable, but not much. Very nice! (0.341l bottle traded from glouglouburp. 2007 vintage.)

Thanks to MDS for the bottle.  Rich brown, thin tan head. Nose is lots of soy, chocolate, plum, tobacco, some peanut.  Flavor is toffee, chocolate, tootsie roll, some alcohol.  Tootsie roll/toffee finish.

341ml brown bottle. 2007 vintage, from Goldorak. Pours dark red-brown colour with a large smooth, thick tan head. Some patchy lacing. The beer is slightly hazy and it looks slightly viscous. Aroma has a trace of yeast and cloves underneath some sweet toffeeish malt. Flavour is a bit sweet with rich caramel malt, mild chocolate, raisins, banana, light citrus (lemon), and some dryish wheat notes. Some alcoholic presence, but theres enough other flavours going on that it doesnt overpower. Aftertaste is clovey with lingering wheat. Full bodied, light tingly carbonation. Drank slightly out of season but it held up quite well. Definately the best beer Ive had from this brewer so far.

Pours a murky brown color with reddish highlights and a medium, bubbly, beige head. Nice aroma of bubble-gum, mild roasted malt, candy and maybe honey. The flavor is mainly focused on the candy and honey sweetness, theres also a bubble-gummy yeast and a mild roasted malt that provides some balance to the sweetness, preventing the beer from being too sweet. The light to medium body has a smoothness provided by the wheat, the texture is slightly sticky and liquorous, the carbonation is moderate. Very well-done, a solid weizen bock.

2007 edition, 12oz bottle from La Trappe A Fromage in Gatineau.  Pours very dark.  Aroma is smoky but relatively faint, and completely misleading.  First taste makes my head shake.  Lots of flavour with cloying sweetness.  The alcohol is evident... and welcomed, at the moment!  Im not getting much weizen out of this weizenbock, but its still a enjoyable drink.

Thanks to maniac for bringing a bottle of this back for me to try.  Very deep brown, creamy head fades slow, little bubbles surprisingly persistent here.  Aroma is deep caramel, a hint of clove, a spice I cant quite put my finger on, a bit of roasty wort, and faint alcohol at the end.  Flavor is a malty dose of caramle, a touch of which has been barely burnt, followed by some herbal spiciness and some cognac alcohol in the finish.  There may be some plum in there as well.  Decent, definitely had some complexities going on.

341ml bottle from Glouglouburp, 2007 (why is it already retired?).  Another weird thing, there is no English on the bottle, its all in French. Isnt that against the law or something?  Pours dark brown with a small head but a rather sticky lacing.  Aroma is strong, starts off boozy, prune-y maltiness then comes lots of dark fruits, some light herbal-ness, some faint cereal.  Taste is similarly dominated with boozy prunes and some light chocolate.  Aftertaste is long with chocolate and slight over-rip plums and some alcohol. Slight warming on the tongue. A medium-light beer with a slightly fizzy mouthfeel from the carbonation.  A bit more than half way done with the bottle and starting to feel the alcohol.
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text: Chocolate, dark fruit and alcohol greet the nose with nutty, sherry-like undertones.  Opaque brown body is topped by a low but lasting brown head that leaves some spotty lacing.  Very sweet malt character is balanced by darked malt bitterness.  Fruitiness emerges especially in the aftertaste.  Medium light body with moderate carbonation.  Floral and marzipan flavours emerge as it warms.  Bottle (Trade, May-07) sampled with Oakes in June 2007.  Thanks, MartinT!
Leftover from RBSG. Cloudy dark brown body with a medium creamy light brown head. Sweet molassas and banana aroma. Sweet molassas, banana, caramel and fruit flavors.

12 oz bottle that I found in my cooler after RBSG 2007. Thanks to whoever brought this! 2007 vintage. Cloudy reddish brown with a brown head. Nice, thick lace. Rich caramel nose, light banana, molasses, raisin and clove all jump out. Very rich body. Chewy malts, molasses and fruit flavors dominate, and the spices meander in late - clove, something peppery and a bit of yeastiness and banana. Excellent stuff - is there such a thing as an Imperial Weizen? No alcohol noticed, shocking at 10%.

Very dark brown in colour, large dissipating tan coloured head, light lacing.  The aroma is rich, slightly burnt, lots of earthy malts, dark fruits, good sweetness, some chocolate.  The flavour has some yeast, dark fruits, chocolate, chewy, some light alcohol starts to come through.  Full mouthfeel, medium/large body, high carbonation.  Finishes warm with a lingering malty sweetness.  Alcohol isnt overpowering, good balance, smooth for a 10% beer.  This brewery is starting to get exciting.

Its a very big rendition of the style, and the maltiness definitely stands up to overwhelm some of the fruitiness/phenolicness youd expect from the style. Very dark brown. Thick lasting brown head. Smells like a dusty chocolate banana. Creamy body. Loads of chocolate up front. Big alcohol wave finish (Tsunami!). A bit sticky sweet. Banana is softer in flavour than in aroma.

Bouteille 2006. De couleur brune foncée et voilée. Nez de levures fruitées aigres et aux notes vineuses, terreuses et boisées (prunes, pruneaux, raisins vineux, dates, notes de bananes), malté de caramel (notes rôties), léger de chocolat noir, de mélasse, de réglisse noire et dalcool doux vineux avec des notes herbeuses et épicées (notes de muscade). Moyenne-ronde en bouche avec un pétillement moyen et une texture crémeuse aux notes vineuses et sirupeuses. Goût de levures fruitées légèrement vineuses, boisées et aux notes terreuses et sûres (prunes, raisins vineux, moyen de dates, léger de pruneaux et de figues, petites notes de bananes) avec un léger goût épicé (notes de muscade) et avec des notes de réglisse noire et un petit caractère végétal lors de lentrée en bouche auquel se rajoute un goût malté sucré de caramel toffee légèrement rôti, léger de chocolat noir ainsi que des notes de blé rôti, de sucre brun et de mélasse sucrée parallèlement à un goût moyennement amer dalcool légèrement vineux et réchauffant jusquen finale avec un léger goût de houblon herbeux. Post-goût long, moyennement amer dalcool légèrement vineux, de rôti et de chocolat noir avec un goût fruité (moût de raisins, pelures de prunes, dates) aux petites notes boisées.

Excellente bière de cette Micro-Brasserie. Le genre de bière pour les connaisseurs, car ma blonde a quessiment craché la gorgé que je lui ai fait boire. 10% dalcool bien caché, où je suis peut être trop habitué à boire des bières fortes que celle-ci ne goûte pas ses 10%. Un produit à racheté nimporte quand.

Bottle from quebec. Super-dark weizen bock, very sweet and malty. Pour is very interesting in that it is superbly dark at its core, but light brown highlights shine throughout the beer. A nice biege cap sits on top. Aroma is vinous and malty,caramel, hearts of palm, peas. Lots of very sweet, gooey, cheap chocolate sticks out in the flavor, complimented by thick molasses and a kind of gravy taste. Thick and warming in the mouth. Atypical for a weizenbock for sure but a very solid beer. Especially at 10%, this makes a fantastic winter beer. Too bad its already spring!

Somethings wrong with the aroma tomato paste? eggs?  Taste is very fruity with raisins, dates, dark grapes, figs and more.  Very sweet with a definite brown sugar flavour.  Heres that tomato paste again, go away!  Thankfully the beer is brutally strong and overly sweet thus helping to mask the problem.  Finish leaves a burnt brown sugar after-taste.  Most of the beer is good but theres a burnt something or rotten something in there that just didnt sit well with me.  This is the 2006 version.  I heard a 2007 batch just got released.  Worth a retry, Ill get a bottle from the new batch (reason to drink a beer #1,642,595)

Any first impressions?
-A rich, full head of foam proudly crowns the cloudy purple-tinged dark brown.
-Quirky plums and herbal spiciness dont quite match with the underlying leather component in the nose.
-Bold black grapes are succulently leaking into the filling fruit cake, as hoppy bitterness attempts to balance things out. Too complex a flavor profile to be assessed on the first sips.
-The portly body is well-carbonated with lively yet soft bubbling, which fits the style.

What if you dig deeper?
-Alcohol warming is fitting, and never intrusive.
-Prunes and dates emerge from the port wine sweetness, and the non-denominational hoppy strength is seamlessly segued.
-A smidge of tartness clashes with the leather in the aroma (with iodine beneath?), and this worries me somewhat, especially for aging purposes.
-Its flavor and body are stupendously developed and comforting, this is a marvelous creation from Trois Mousquetaires. Imagine the flavor profile of Aventinus Weizen-Eisbock and carbonate it à la Aventinus Weizenbock, add a surreptitious leather whip, and youve got yourself a fascinating rendition of this broad and underdeveloped style.

Bottle; 2006 vintage.

Warming crunched cereal juice, prune puree, molasses and leather make for a rich and satisfying nose. Quite yeasty, yet residual sugars and concentration are the dominant aspect. Cloudy medium brown hue is kept from darkness by the shy wheat. Wearing a fine light beige crown that mostly lasts. Plenty of persistence in the finish, with rancio flavors emerging on top of the phenols. Tastes like it has been lagered for a while. Full creamy body displaying smooth carbonation that is one of its few differences from liquorous late-evening drink, almost playing in the ballpark of Samichlaus in that regard. Concentrated fruitiness through and through with lots of boldness, earthy and leathery. Kinda sticky after a few sips, but does not grow hard to drink and the alcohol remains under control despite its warmth. Impressive winter beer.

Au nez, quelques vestiges éthérés du travail de la levure de weizen, de même quun léger arôme de mélasse qui laisse présager une bonne dose de malt. À loeil, brune opaque, un peu trouble. Mousse dorée qui se fait discrète. Au goût, rondeur en bouche incroyable. Malt corpulent dont le goût reste imprégné pendant plusieurs secondes. Les 10% dalcool sont bien ressentis.  Une superbe bière dhiver, jai pour mions dire!
